Heark!— I hear the Alderman— Run in— Run in— I'll follow you instantly. [Exeunt Mrs. Whitebroth, and Mrs. Mopus.] So— Now 'tis 400 l. a year, and not Conform:— The women are good comfortable women, and I ought not in Conscience to leave 'um:— But hear me Brother— What will you do with your new Parsonage?— Why— I— will— get— some or other instituted, and inducted into 't, to save a Lapse, and take a Bond of 500 l. of him, to resign at six Months; which, he will forfeit of course, as
not doubting but to be reliev'd against it, as Simoniacal:— So— There's 500 l. got too— He's gone every way:— At common Law, 'tis his own Bond; In equity, he might have resign'd:— But why so fast friend Scruple? Had not you as good sell it out-right to avoid dispute?— I cannot tell— But now I remember me, The Casuists take a notable difference, that is to say, between money given (provalore Beneficii) as the full price, and (tanquam motivum ad resignandum) for your good will, or so;— The first, they generally agree to be Simony; but for the latter, they leave it as a controverted point, positivelie deny'd by verie few, but such as have no money to give. [Enter Whitebroth, led by Mopus and Timothy, Whitebroth Coughs.] Alas good Sir!— How does your Worship?— Pray Sir how do you like him?

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Troth but ill; I'm half afraid of him.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Who's that? Mr. Scruple?

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: Yes Sir— How do you?

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Uh— Uh— Verie ill— Is the Doctor coming?

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: He'll be here immediatelie— Poor man! He was half distracted when I brought him the News— [Enter Runter.] He's come:— How he sweats with haste!

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: My dear Friend, how do you?

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Oh— Oh— ill, ill:— Uh— Uh— Uh— Have you brought my old Will with you?— Let me see't. Uh— Uh— Uh—

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: Yes Sir, here 'tis. [Runter gives it Whitebroth, he peruses it.]

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: Indeed Sir 'tis piouslie, and discreetlie done, to settle Affairs so, that there may be no wrangling, in case you should do otherwise than well.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I wonder my Boy comes not— I have sent him for a Rosy-Crucian preparation, has fetcht a man again, after he has been dead a day, and half:— I hope it may do good; However, for fear of the worst, you do well to settle your Estate, it may ease your head.

sp.speaker: Wb.
sp.p: Uh— Uh— Uh— Here Doctor— Put some wax to't;— Set the Table nearer— And give me my Seal— [Runter in putting on the wax, puts the change upon him; he signs and seals the false Deed, and Coughs all the while.]

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: Sir you are weak:— Do you deliver this as your Act and Deed?

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Yes— I do— Pray Gentlemen be Witnesses to it. [Enter Boy. They witness it.]

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Oh— Are you come at last— Here Sir— Here's the most soveraign Cordial in all the World— I was seven years, in making one poor pint, and half of't.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: I thank you Sir— He drinks— Uh— Uh— It warms me strangelie— Uh— Uh—

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Pray forbear Coughing,— you are weak— How do you feel your self now?

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: I cannot tell— But methinks it does me good.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I see by this sudden operation, 'twill do the work:— You were best to walk in, and rest your self in your Couch awhile, before the fire.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: I must run home a little, upon some urgent occasions, but will see you again presentlie. Exeunt severally.

div.head: ACT. V. SCE. 5.
div.stage: Enter D. Diligence, and his wife; Bil. T. T. The men, drunk.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: WHy Captain— What? All a mort?

sp.speaker: T. T.
sp.p: Faith I was contemplating upon the pence.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: And thou shal't have 'um Boy— See here my Bully!— [He pulls out Whitebroth's Chain.—] Here's that will fetch 'um.

sp.speaker: M. D.
sp.p: Dear Major give it me.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Thou shal't have anie thing my Jo:— Captain, Courage! We'll be merrie to Night, and have a Wedding, though't be but a Westminster one.

sp.speaker: T. T.
sp.p: What you will.

sp.speaker: D. D.
sp.p: Well said Major:— Ah for a Fiddle now:— Odds nigs!

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: I hate those Puritan Oaths— If thou must swear, swear like a man of Office.

sp.speaker: D. D.
sp.p: The old Boy still— Now could I Caper through the Moon:— Hey Tosse— Hang one Fiddle, we'll have a whole Kennel:— Come you Jade— Dance.

sp.speaker: M. D.
sp.p: Alas Major— How pitifullie my Husband is cut!— He'll be so sick tomorrow morning.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Yes faith;— He has got a Rattle as big as a Drum.

sp.speaker: D. D.
sp.p: Major!— A word— Do you think my Wife's a Whore?

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Such another word— And— By all the bones of my back—

sp.speaker: D. D.
sp.p: Nay good Major— I was once a little jealous, till she told you of the Aldernian— But now, I dare trust her to Lecture by her self.

sp.speaker: M. D.
sp.p: What's that you say of me? [Enter Afterwitt, Beatrice, Jolly, Runter, Cis.]

sp.speaker: D. D.
sp.p: Stand— Who comes there?— Knock 'um down?— What are you?— I am the Constable.

sp.speaker: Aft.
sp.p: The Fellow's mad.

sp.speaker: M. D.
sp.p: No Sir, he's onlie a little overtaken as they say.

sp.speaker: D. D.
sp.p: Stand off— Down with 'um— Stand— Treason— I command you to apprehend one another.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.p: Maine a good time, has this Fellows head been broke, to keep the peace whole— 'Prithee take him away.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Landlord— They're friends.

sp.speaker: D. D.
sp.p: Which— Where— Here I could have 'um, and there I could have 'um:— [He fences with his staffe:—] Mr. Runter!— I profess I knew you not.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: Then ha'done now— Come Gentlemen, What say you? The business must be discovered first or last, and as good now (and perhaps better) than another time.

sp.speaker: Aft.
sp.p: I like it well— But think it were not amiss to lessen the Company— We will not appear all at once.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: However let 'um be within call.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.p: Pray Gentlemen keep together— We shall have occasion to use you presentlie.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: You see my Arm's in a Scarf— Much cannot be expected from me:— But for a dead lift, we'll make a shift to change hands:— Gi' the word of command there, faces about, &c.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.p: And hear me Major— Lend me your Chain:— And let it be you care to provide some abominable Musick:— We'll bring him to our Bow, or run him to death with Fidlers:—

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: I warrant you— Here— [He gives him the Chain. Exeunt all, but Jolly. Aft. Bea.— To them, Enter Scr. Mrs. White-broth.]

sp.speaker: M. W.
sp.p: How! Marry'd? O my Child— My Child!

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: You might have believ'd me sooner— How often have I told you, she was in her Teenes?— And you know Teene, quasi Teeming:— I may be a little free with you— Young Girls are like Nuts, you must gather them when they begin to be brown at bottom, or they'll fall of themselves.

sp.speaker: M. W.
sp.p: But trulie, I hope it is not so plain as you make it.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: How think you? [Afterwitt and Beatrice, come up and kneel.]

sp.speaker: M. W.
sp.p: O my Child, my Child— Thy father is prettie hoddie again, but this will break his heart quite— O my Child— Has he not hurt thee? [Enter Whitebroth, Mopus, Timothy, After them, Mrs. Mopus.]

sp.speaker: Aft.
sp.p: No great sign of death Mother.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: What's all this clutter?— Here's a noise for a sick man, with all my heart!— [Afterwitt and Beatrice kneel to him.] How's this?

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: Nothing but Matrimonie Sir, and Conjugal Love.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: And were you Pimp to't?— I hope you have made sure of her portion— I can assure you her Grandfather left her not so much as a grey Groat.

sp.speaker: Aft.
sp.p: I have enough in her.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Much good may't do you.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Good Sir forgive me.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Out of my doors— The wench is prettie handsome, and will be able to get her own living, if the Parish will but keep the Children.

sp.speaker: Aft.
sp.p: I must not hear this language— Know you this— A good honest settlement upon my self. [He shews the Deed.] And your Daughter in consideration of marriage.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Ha! Settlement! And in consideration of Marriage!— I was not drunk sure!— When was this done?

sp.speaker: Aft.
sp.p: Onlie a little Crop sick— Verie latelie.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, you desir'd this Gentleman, and my self, to be Witnesses to it— I know my hand again.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I saw you sign, seal, and deliver it.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: I publish't onlie my Will.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I know not what your meaning was; but you deliver'd it as your Act, and Deed.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Timothy— Fetch me the Constable.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.p: Sir, he'll save you that trouble; I met him just coming to you, about a suspitious person, whom he apprehended with This Chain in his pocket. [He shews the Chain.] You cannot imagine whose it should be? [Whitebroth makes no answer, but holds up his hands, and walks:— Enter full but upon him, Bilboe, Double Diligence, Titere Tu, and Mrs. Double Diligence.]

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Cheated— Cheated— As I'm an Alderman, purelie Cheated.

sp.speaker: Aft.
sp.p: How can that be— you have the Reputation, of as shrewd a man, as anie upon the Bench.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Ah— Rogues all— Rogues all— [He walks again.]

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.p: What say you Sir? Here's the Constable now:— Come, come, be wise:— Your Daughter has marry'd a Gentleman:— Is not this better, than a Smithfield bargain?— Give me so much money, and my Horse shall leap your Mare.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Don't worrie me with words— I'll consider of't.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: Good Sir— Marriages are made in Heaven.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Then I'll be sworn, I had nev'r a friend there.

sp.speaker: Cis.
sp.p: Trulie nor I neither— For indeed, methinks they are verie long in coming down. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: Now verilie Sir, but this is a just judgment upon you, for hoarding up your moneys, and suffering the Good Old Cause to starve.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Seriech-owle:— But where's my Doctor?

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.p: Why troth Sir (you cannot blame him) he is somewhat loth to appear, till he see how things are like to go:— Come, pray Sir—

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Well Sir— I see by this Chain, the Major and you, understand one another— Let's have no more words— All parties shall be satisfy'd— Give me't.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.p: There— And may you long live to wear't:— You may come down— All's well— [To Runter, peeping above.]

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Come Son and Daughter, the business is done, and I forgive you both— And if that settlement be not large enough, I'll make you a new one upon demand— You shall have your own Estate back, in present, and as you love your Wife, the rest after our deaths:— And so, you have my blessing.

sp.speaker: Aft.
sp.p: Bea. [Kneel.] We thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Come, let's be merrie— And as late as 'tis send for the Musick— We must have a Dance, at least.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.p: See what 'tis to forecast a mans business right;— They are gone for, and will be here instantlie.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: But we forget the main thing, the Posset:— Quicklie Cis, and get one readie. Exit Cis.

sp.speaker: M. W.
sp.p: How's this? Musique! Dancing! Posset!— Are they lawful good Mr. Scruple?

sp.speaker: M. M.
sp.p: Are they not, Raggs of the Whore?

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: Thereafter as they may be us'd— I will consider it a little, and give you my opinion— [He walks. Enter Runter.]

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: O my Doctor— You're a fine Gentleman— Good faith you are.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: Who I?— I care not if all my faults were writ in my forehead:— [Enter Tyro.]

sp.speaker: Wh
sp.p: It must be in short hand then, or there will want room.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.p: Here's Tyro, too— Your ev'n come time enough to dance at your Mistresses Wedding!

sp.speaker: Ty.
sp.p: How! My Mistresses Wedding?

sp.speaker: T. T.
sp.p: Even so— Alas that I had but known of this before!

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: Women will have their wills— Let her go— I have another guess thing, in chase for you.

sp.speaker: Ty.
sp.p: And shall I have her?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: Thou shalt— And heark you— [Runter having whisper'd him, he shruggs, and scratches his elbow.]

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: Hum— I am full; and shall discourse 'um graduallie:— And first, of the first— Musick;— Yes certainlie, it is lawful— But, what Musick? That's the question:— We'll examine it a little— Cimbals, they are Jewish,— The Harp, malignant, and Irish;— Organs, Antichristian;— The Fluit, a meer Horn-pipe;— The Fiddle, Out upon't! Most abominable, it ushers in Revels, and May-poles:— What then?— Why trulie I agree with the Assembly— Bag-pipes;— A harmless, innocent Musick, and most agreeable, to the Discipline, and practice, of our Bretheren of the Kirk:— Besides, it has (as the Learned observe) a specifick qualitie, to mollifie, and soften the most brutal natures— Witness, the Bears— Emollit mores nec sinit esse feros.— But secondly, for Dancing— Why trulie, that may be lawful too— But here too, the point will be the same;— What Dancing?— Countrey Dances; they are Pagan;— French Dances; Fye, Fye, Antick;— Our ordinarie dancing; villanous; 'tis mixt, and promiscuous, a verie Nicolait●●ism:— The Benchers measures; I must confess they come somewhat near, were they not superstitious:— What then?— Why— The men may dance in one Room, and the women in t'other:— Lastly, for the Posset— And truly here, I'm in a great Wood— But not to dwell upon the Letter, whither Posset, or P-osset, I shall take it as it lies before me— Posset— And truly that may be lawful too:— Lemon Posset, is cooling— Carduus Posset, Benedictus— And Sack-Posset, comfortable— But VVedding— Sack— Posset— There's the point;— Trulie, I half doubt it, and that for fifteen Reasons— Hum—

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.p: A plague o' these Fidlers— VVe shall be murder'd ere they come.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: I say for fifteen Reasons:— First, from the name of the thing; Posset, from Posse, To be able; And from that fond supposition, first brought into VVeddings, An invention, meerly carnal:— But secondly, for that it ministreth abundance of unsavoury discourse:— Thirdly, for that the Grace before it, is none at all, and the Grace after it, lewd:— Fourthly, That it is eaten (by the parties chiefly concern'd) only in spight:— Fithly,— Hum— Haw— I say fifthly— [Enter Fiddles.]

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.p: Servavit Apollo!— Strike up, strike up— One noise best drowns another.

sp.speaker: Sc.
sp.p: A wholsome observation lost.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.p: 'Twill keep cold for another time.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen— One Dance, and then for the Posset, [They dance. Tyro pipes.] VVhy so— vve're all friends— And now, you that are for the Posset, follow me.

sp.speaker: Jol.
sp.p: VVell mov'd— VVell mov'd— The Bride begins to be sleepy.

sp.speaker: Bil.
sp.p: Lead on before there— I'll bring up the Rear— Come Landlord— Bear up for the Bar of Chester; And since we have had so good fortune to day, we'll henceforth boyle our Beef in Sack, and make the Beggars drunk with the Porridge. Exeunt.

lg.l: I Had almost forgot— Let's see— What weather?
Nor fair;— Nor foul;— Indifferent;— Both together,
Clear, if no Clouds, nor misling;— If there shou'd,
It shall proceed from former Causes:— Good:
So much for Doctrine— To Apply it now;
Yo've had A Play, But, whither good, or No,
'Tis past my Globe,— yet guess, the weather will
Prove fair enough, unless you make it ill.
'Tis you must make the Play, or stand, or fall;
Therefore, By me, To you, and you, and All,
The Author bows— And perhaps reason for 't;
Some Men the Judge, others, the Jury Court;
The one, more Just, if unconcern'd; The other,
More Pitiful; If he claps both together,
He means no hurt; For in a common Hall,
Noise carries it— He fain would please you All:
Yo've had for Pit, for Box, for Gallery too;
Keep your own Posts, and he is well enou':
But— If you must lash out, And think you can't
Be wits your selves, unless you pique, and rant;
At your own Peril be't, And further know,
Who gives a Character, in one, gives two:
He hopes the best— Nor will we, be perplext;
Laugh hearty now, and he shall fix you next.
